d: A passage between rows of seats in a building such as a church or theater, an airplane, or a train.
e: the musical had the audience dancing in the aisles

d: The action or process of arriving.
e: Ruth's arrival in New York

d: Personal belongings packed in suitcases for traveling; luggage.
e: we collected our baggage before clearing customs

d: A long, thin, flat piece of wood or other hard material, used for floors or other building purposes.
e: loose boards creaked as I walked on them

d: A pass for boarding an aircraft, given to passengers when checking in.
e: In the second step, the passenger takes the boarding pass to the bag check location, where an agent scans in the pass and luggage tags are printed and attached.

d: A dividing wall or barrier between compartments in a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle.
e: The frigates have a double-skinned hull divided by ten bulkheads into watertight compartments.

d: A bag or suitcase taken onto an aircraft as handheld luggage.
A horse-drawn carriage, especially a closed one.
e: It was a wonderful sight to see because many of the guests arrived in horse-drawn coaches and carriages.

d: A compartment for the pilot, and sometimes also the crew, in an aircraft or spacecraft.
e: Today, the Air Force involuntarily removes young pilots from the cockpits of manned aircraft for 36 months to ‘fly’ unmanned aerial vehicles.

d: A relationship in which a person, thing, or idea is linked or associated with something else.
e: the connections between social attitudes and productivity

d: A group of people who work on and operate a ship, boat, aircraft, spacecraft, or train.
e: he was one of nine members of the crew killed when the plane went down

d: Say something in a solemn and emphatic manner.
e: “I was under too much pressure,” he declared

d: The action of leaving, especially to start a journey.
e: the day of departure

d: Exempt from payment of duty.
e: the permitted number of duty-free goods

d: A set of people or things grouped together as the best.
A steward or stewardess on an aircraft.
e: The flight engineer became unconscious after reviving the flight attendant.

d: The cockpit of a large aircraft.
e: The aircraft has state-of-the-art flight deck, avionics and navigation equipment.

d: A hinged barrier used to close an opening in a wall, fence, or hedge.
e: she closed the front gate

d: A planned route or journey.
e: his itinerary included an official visit to Canada

d: An engine using jet propulsion for forward thrust, mainly used for aircraft.
e: Most modern high-speed aircraft use a very different type of engine - the jet engine.

d: Extreme tiredness and other physical effects felt by a person after a long flight across different time zones.
e: she was suffering from jet lag and needed to rest

d: A very large person or thing.
An instance of coming or bringing something to land, either from the air or from water.
e: we made a perfect landing at the airstrip

d: A room or compartment with a toilet and washbasin; a bathroom.
e: he locked himself in the downstairs lavatory

d: Suitcases or other bags in which to pack personal belongings for traveling.
e: upon landing, we waited and waited for our luggage

d: Moving or allowing movement in one direction only.
e: a one-way valve

d: Accept more reservations for (a flight or hotel) than there is room for.
e: airlines deliberately overbook some scheduled flights

d: A mask placed over the nose and mouth and connected to a supply of oxygen, used when the body is not able to gain enough oxygen by breathing air, for example at high altitudes, or because of a medical condition.
e: When you wake up you may find that you have an oxygen mask over your mouth and nose.

d: An official document issued by a government, certifying the holder's identity and citizenship and entitling them to travel under its protection to and from foreign countries.
e: a British citizen with a valid passport does not need a visa to visit the US

d: A person who operates the flying controls of an aircraft.
e: a strike by local airline pilots

d: A mechanical device for propelling a boat or aircraft, consisting of a revolving shaft with two or more broad, angled blades attached to it.
e: One engine on the top of the aircraft is attached to large propellers that produce lift, much like a helicopter.

d: A journey to one or more places and back again, especially by a route that does not cover the same ground twice.
e: The round trip is a whopping 12,400 miles, and Nicole's journey is the fastest known return migration of any swimming animal, the researchers say.

d: A leveled strip of smooth ground along which aircraft take off and land.
e: the jet braked hard as its wheels touched the runway

d: A belt used to secure someone in the seat of a motor vehicle or aircraft.
e: They should only wear a two-point lap belt if a three-point seat belt is not available.

d: The state of being free from danger or threat.
e: the system is designed to provide maximum security against toxic spills

d: Readiness for duty or immediate deployment.
e: buses were placed on standby for the trip to Washington

d: A break in a journey.
e: the one-day stopover in Honolulu

d: The action of becoming airborne.
e: the plane accelerated down the runway for takeoff

d: A boat or other means of transportation used to convey passengers in return for payment of a fare.
e: I'll take a taxi from the air terminal

d: Violent or unsteady movement of air or water, or of some other fluid.
e: the plane shuddered as it entered some turbulence

d: An endorsement on a passport indicating that the holder is allowed to enter, leave, or stay for a specified period of time in a country.
e: a tourist visa

d: A seat below a window, especially one in a bay or alcove.
e: It had a huge wardrobe with mirror doors and a window with a padded window seat that looked out at the quiet tree-lined street below.

d: (in a bird) a modified forelimb that bears large feathers and is used for flying.
e: Besides having forelimbs that resemble the wings of modern birds, the animal sported long feathers from thigh to foot on each hind limb.
